content: The main means of access to Kusatsu Onsen are express bus, route bus, train, and private car. Express buses run from Tokyo Station and Shinjuku Station South Exit (Busta Shinjuku) via the "Joshū Yumeguri-go," with fares ranging from 3,700 yen to 4,100 yen for adults. From Yokohama, buses run from Yokohama Station, Shin-Yokohama Station, and Tamaplaza Station at 3,900 yen to 4,500 yen for adults. From Omiya, Kawagoe, and Takasaki, fares are 3,000 yen to 4,000 yen for adults; from Ikebukuro and Tokyo, 3,000 yen to 3,500 yen for adults; and from Kichijoji, reservations are required at 3,800 yen for adults. Route buses run from Naganohara-Kusatsuguchi Station to Kusatsu Onsen in about 25 minutes at 780 yen for adults. From Karuizawa Station, Kusakaru Kotsu Bus or Seibu Kanko Bus operates at 2,240 yen for adults. By train, the JR Limited Express "Kusatsu-Shima" takes about 2 hours 18 minutes from Ueno Station to Naganohara-Kusatsuguchi Station; from Tokyo Station, the Hokuriku Shinkansen takes about 1 hour 10 minutes to Karuizawa Station. By car, it is about 163 km via Nerima IC and Shibukawa-Ikaho IC. Winter tires and tire chains are essential in winter.

Yubatake (hot water field) is the symbol of Kusatsu Onsen and is located in the center of the hot spring town. Approximately 4,000 liters of hot spring water gush out every minute, and the rising steam is spectacular. Hot water flows slowly through the wooden conduits in the center of the Yubatake, cooling the water temperature from over 50°C before being distributed to various facilities. As the water flows through the conduits, hot spring minerals precipitate to form "yunohana" (hot spring crystals). The distinctive emerald green color of the Yubatake is caused by "Ideyukogome," a type of algae that thrives in acidic hot springs. Lighting is displayed from sunset until midnight, offering a fantastical night view with ever-changing colors. The surrounding area features the foot bath "Yukemuri-tei" and "Tearainoyu," where you can wash your hands with sterilizing hot spring water.

section: Kusatsu Onsen Specialty "Yumomi and Dance" Show
content: The famous "Yumomi and Dance" show of Kusatsu Onsen is held daily at "Netsunoyu," a Taisho Romanesque-style building standing in front of the Yubatake. Yumomi is a method devised in the Edo period to cool the temperature of Kusatsu Onsen's source water, which is about 50°C, without adding water and diluting its efficacy. The show features dances including the Kusatsu-bushi performed by yumomi maidens, with the climactic "O-momi" (grand yumomi) where water splashes up to the ceiling being spectacular. Performance times are 9:30, 10:00, 10:30, 15:30, 16:00, and 16:30. Admission is 700 yen for adults and 350 yen for elementary school students. Every Sunday and Monday, there is a program where you can actually experience yumomi; participation is 300 yen for elementary school students and above between 11:30 and 13:00. Additionally, "Kusatsu Onsen Rakugo" is held at Netsunoyu every evening from 20:00, at 1,200 yen for adults and 600 yen for children.

Sainokawara Park is about a 10-minute walk from the Yubatake. It is a rare park covering approximately 8.5 square kilometers where hot springs gush from throughout the grounds. It is free to stroll 24 hours a day, and lighting is displayed from sunset until midnight. The park features the large-scale "Sainokawara Open-Air Bath." Urakusatsu Jizo is a new area renovated in 2021, located about a 3-minute walk from the Yubatake. The area features a unified wooden design with "Manga-do" (housing about 10,000 volumes of works by authors connected to Kusatsu Onsen), "Jizo Cafe Tsuki no Kao," and "Hyakunen Ishi Bekkyaku" for hot spring art experiences. "Kao-yu" (face bath), "Tearainoyu" (hand-washing bath), and foot baths have also been newly installed, allowing you to experience Kusatsu Onsen with your whole body. From the observation deck, you can enjoy the scenery of all four seasons, and at night, fantastical lighting is displayed.

section: Kusatsu Three Baths and Public Bathhouses
content: The three representative hot springs of Kusatsu Onsen are called "Kusatsu Three Baths." Otakinoyu is known for "awase-yu" (combined bath), where you bathe in hot springs of different temperatures in sequence. On the 2nd and 4th Saturdays of each month, it offers "Hakudaku no Hi" (White Turbidity Day) with premium cloudy water from the Niekawa source with its sulfur aroma. Hours are 9:00 to 21:00; admission is 1,200 yen for adults and 600 yen for children. Goza-no-yu is adjacent to the Yubatake and is a beautiful wooden public bathhouse recreating Edo and Meiji architecture; it also offers "outdoor yukata rental." Hours are 7:00 to 21:00 from April to November, and 8:00 to 21:00 from December to March; admission is 900 yen for adults and 450 yen for children. Sainokawara Open-Air Bath boasts one of the largest facilities in Japan with an overwhelming sense of openness. Every Friday from 17:30 to 20:00, it becomes a mixed-gender bath with swimsuits or similar attire. Admission is 800 yen for adults and 400 yen for children. The "Choi-na Three Baths Pass" allows economical use of all three facilities at 2,100 yen for adults and 1,050 yen for children, with no expiration date. Public bathhouses include Shirahata-no-yu (free, 8:00–23:00), Chiyo-no-yu (free, 6:00–23:00), and Jizo-no-yu (free, 8:00–22:00).

Onsen Gate is Kusatsu Onsen's new entrance, completed in October 2023. The grade separation of National Route 292 has alleviated traffic congestion, and it has become a landmark of Kusatsu Onsen with its wood-carved design. At night, lighting is displayed, and you can enjoy a foot bath fed by hot spring water at your feet. It is a facility that can be called a satellite of the Yubatake, with approximately 600 liters of water flowing per minute from three wooden conduits. It is available 24 hours and has a free parking lot for 101 vehicles. For getting around Kusatsu Onsen town, the retro-designed town circulation bus is convenient at 100 yen per ride. Route A runs from Kusatsu Onsen Bus Terminal to the Yubatake, Otakinoyu, Sainokawara Park, Kusatsu Onsen Ski Resort, and more, useful for town sightseeing. Major parking lots include Yubatake Tourist Parking (180 spaces), Sainokawara Park Parking (120 spaces), and Onsen Gate Parking (101 spaces, free).

section: Kusatsu Onsen Ski Resort and Activities
content: Snow Resort Kusatsu Onsen Ski Resort is a vast ski resort with a maximum course length of 4,300 m and an elevation difference of 355 m. The "Pulse Gondola Tengu," which opened in late 2023, features 3-car cabins and takes you to the summit of Tengu Mountain while overlooking the hot spring town; you can also enjoy the view from the summit in seasons other than winter. One-way fares are 800 yen for adults and 600 yen for children; round-trip fares are 1,500 yen for adults and 1,000 yen for children. At the summit observation restaurant "Crystal Tengu Oozeki," you can enjoy authentic sushi while viewing the surrounding mountains. The zip line "BanZip TENGU" is an activity spanning approximately 500 m with a 108 m elevation difference, descending at a top speed of about 70 km/h; the fee is 2,000 yen for adults and 1,200 yen for children. Japan's tallest swing at 10 m high, "Kusatsu Onsen SKY-SWING," can be experienced for 600 yen for adults and 500 yen for children. The Kids Park is equipped with a giant inflatable play structure, a sled and snow racer exclusive slope, and a snow escalator, so families can play with peace of mind. A new Tengu Mountain rest house is scheduled for completion in spring 2026.

section: History and Spring Quality of Kusatsu Onsen
content: The history of Kusatsu Onsen dates back to ancient times. Kusatsu Town is located on a plateau at approximately 1,200 meters above sea level, with a natural discharge of over 32,000 liters per minute—enough to fill 160 ordinary bathtubs in one minute. The spring quality is strongly acidic at around pH 2, with sterilizing properties; it is said to be effective for skin diseases, cuts, burns, and more, and has long been said to "cure everything except lovesickness." Hayashi Razan is said to have selected Arima, Gero, and Kusatsu as "Japan's Three Famous Hot Springs," and in the Edo period, the water was transported to the Tokugawa shogunate as "offering water." In the Meiji period, the German physician Dr. Baelz visited Kusatsu Onsen, proved its medical effectiveness, and introduced it to the world as "a world-class hot spring health resort." Kusatsu Onsen has over 100 hot spring sources in total, and six major sources (Yubatake, Sainokawara, Jizo, Niekawa, Shirahata, and Bandai) supply the hot spring town.

section: Kusatsu Onsen's Unique Hot Spring Culture
content: Kusatsu Onsen has developed three unique hot spring cultures: "yumomi," "Yubatake," and "awase-yu." Yumomi was devised because Kusatsu Onsen's source water is about 50°C, and a method was needed to lower the temperature without adding water so as to preserve its efficacy. It softens the water and also serves as a warm-up for bathing. The Yubatake is the symbol of Kusatsu Onsen, a hot spring source located in the center of town; hot water flows slowly through wooden conduits to cool the temperature from over 50°C before distributing it to various facilities. Awase-yu is Kusatsu's unique bathing method of bathing in tubs of different temperatures in order from lukewarm to hot, designed to promote blood circulation while minimizing strain on the body and to maximize the effects of the hot spring. Efficacy is expected in various areas including blood circulation promotion, fatigue recovery, and rheumatism improvement.

section: Kusatsu Onsen Contact Information and Taxi Information
content: General inquiries about Kusatsu Onsen tourism are handled by the Kusatsu Onsen Tourism Association (phone 0279-88-0800). Accommodation reservations and inquiries are handled by the Kusatsu Onsen Ryokan Association (0279-88-3722) from 9:00 to 18:00. Inquiries for Kusatsu Onsen Ski Resort: 0279-88-8111. Taxis are available from Kusatsu Kanko Taxi (0279-88-2450) and Asashiro Kanko Taxi (0279-88-2276). Rental cars are available at Toyota Rent-a-Car Naganohara-Kusatsuguchi Station (0279-82-0100) and T.S. Kogyo (0279-88-3290). Downloading the Kusatsu Onsen official tourism app allows you to check recommended tour plans, restaurant information, and event information in real time, and obtain discount coupons.

Various events are held at Kusatsu Onsen during winter. "Kusatsu Onsen Winter Fireworks" is an event that launches fireworks during the clear winter air; they can be seen from the ski resort area as well as from various locations throughout the town centered on the Yubatake. From the summit of Tengu Mountain, fireworks rise right before your eyes. "Dream Lights" is a fantastical event where approximately 1,200 candles are lit on the stone steps of Kosenji Temple right next to the Yubatake; it is held regardless of season. "Yubatake Tree & Illumination" is an event that sets up a Christmas tree with approximately 40,000 LED decorations on a real fir tree in Yubatake Yuro Plaza. At Kusatsu Onsen Ski Resort, Christmas events include candy presents from Santa Claus to children and New Year's Day sunrise gondola operation.

Several precautions are necessary when visiting Kusatsu Onsen in winter. The average temperature at Kusatsu Onsen drops below freezing, so it gets quite cold to the core. Be sure to bring warm clothing such as thick winter wear and hand warmers. There are many places in the hot spring town where snow has accumulated or surfaces are frozen and slippery, so sightseeing in snow-appropriate footwear such as snow boots is recommended. When visiting by car, studless tires or chains are essential; normal tires can cause accidents or getting stuck. The Shiga-Kusatsu Kogen Route (National Route 292) is closed for the winter from mid-November to late April.

section: Recommended Ways to Enjoy Kusatsu Onsen
content: Recommended ways to enjoy Kusatsu Onsen: First, view the gushing hot spring and steam at the symbolic Yubatake, and watch the famous "Yumomi and Dance" show at Netsunoyu. After that, using the "Choi-na Three Baths Pass" to visit the Kusatsu Three Baths (Otakinoyu, Goza-no-yu, Sainokawara Open-Air Bath) is recommended; the awase-yu at Otakinoyu and the openness of Sainokawara Open-Air Bath are exceptional. Sainokawara Park can be strolled free of charge 24 hours a day, and you can see hot springs gushing from throughout the grounds up close. In the Urakusatsu Jizo area, you can enjoy cafes and foot baths, and at night the Yubatake light-up offers a fantastical view.

Kusatsu Onsen has various sightseeing facilities in addition to hot springs. Kusatsu Tropical Garden is Japan's highest-elevation zoo; the 15-meter-high dome uses geothermal heat to create a subtropical environment. In addition to reptiles such as crocodiles, snakes, and lizards, capybara families are also kept, and you can interact with the animals up close. Admission is 1,300 yen for adults, 1,000 yen for high school students, and 800 yen for children. Kusatsu Tsurutaro Kataoka Art Museum is near Sainokawara Park. Baelz Memorial Hall is located in Michi-no-Eki Kusatsu Undo Chaya Park and introduces the achievements of Dr. Baelz, who introduced Kusatsu Onsen to the world. At Hyakunen Ishi Bekkyaku, you can experience making "Hyakunen Ishi" hot spring art using Kusatsu Onsen's acidic spring quality; drawings and text painted with paint on limestone rise three-dimensionally through the hot spring, and you can take home your one-of-a-kind creation. The experience fee is 800 yen.

section: Efficacy of Kusatsu Onsen and Recommended For
content: Kusatsu Onsen is a strongly acidic spring at around pH 2, with high sterilizing power as its main characteristic. It is said to be effective for skin diseases (chronic eczema, atopic dermatitis, athlete's foot), cuts, burns, neuralgia, joint pain, muscle pain, cold sensitivity, fatigue recovery, and rheumatism. It is especially recommended for those suffering from chronic skin problems and those troubled by atopy or eczema. It is also suitable for business people with shoulder stiffness, lower back pain, or joint pain from desk work or lack of exercise, and those troubled by cold sensitivity. With awase-yu, blood circulation promotion and fatigue recovery can be expected; it is recommended for those who want to thoroughly relieve daily fatigue. However, because the acidity is strong, those with sensitive skin or small children should avoid long baths, and it is recommended to rinse the body with plain water after bathing.
